item.title: Word of the Day: autonomous
item.description: This word has appeared in 378 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Live Updates: Astronauts Head Home After Space Station Medical Evacuation
item.description: Two Americans and astronauts from Japan and Russia are set to splash down in the Pacific Ocean after a medical issue prompted NASA to move up their return to Earth.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:description: The returning crew members in their Crew Dragon pressure suits on Jan. 9. Clockwise from bottom left: NASA astronaut Mike Fincke, Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov, NASA astronaut Zena Cardman and JAXA astronaut Kimiya Yui.

item.title: Las refinerías de EE. UU. se beneficiarán del control de Trump sobre el petróleo venezolano
item.description: Es probable que las empresas que convierten el petróleo en gasolina y diesel tomen la ventaja, comparadas con aquellas que extraen del subsuelo.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott

media:content.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Una refinería de Valero Energy en Houston. Las refinerías estadounidenses están preparadas para obtener ganancias si empieza a fluir más petróleo venezolano hacia Estados Unidos.

item.title: Crane Collapses on Expressway Outside Bangkok, Killing at Least 2
item.description: The deadly episode came a day after a crane fell on a moving train in northeastern Thailand, killing at least 32 people.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

media:content.media:description: The site where a construction crane collapsed onto a highway in Samut Sakhon Province, Thailand, on Thursday.

item.title: Irán alista su primera ejecución ligada a las protestas, mientras Trump advierte represalias
item.description: Organizaciones de derechos humanos y familiares dicen que el país planea la primera ejecución de un manifestante opositor durante la más reciente ola de protestas.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Sanam Mahoozi and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:description: A still from a video posted on social media of cars set on fire during a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Greenlanders Shocked, Angry, Confused and, Most of All, Scared
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 15, 2026.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 15, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 15, 2026.

item.title: Au Pair Testifies of Lurid Plot in Virginia Double-Murder Trial
item.description: Juliana Peres Magalhães wrapped up testimony on Wednesday in the case against Brendan Banfield, her former lover, who is accused of killing his wife and another man.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:description: Juliana Peres Magalhães is escorted into the courtroom before continuing her testimony in the trial of Brendan Banfield in Fairfax County, Va., on Wednesday.

item.title: James Luckey-Lange Among Americans Freed in Venezuela
item.description: James Luckey-Lange, 28, was released this week with several other U.S. citizens from the country’s notorious prison system after going missing in December, his family said.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong

item.title: Venezuelan Immigrants Urge Appeals Court to Restore Deportation Protections
item.description: The Trump administration has ended Temporary Protected Status for about 600,000 Venezuelan immigrants, part of a broader effort to curb avenues for immigrants to remain in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa

media:content.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Border Servant Corps worker helped a Venezuelan woman who had just crossed the border at El Paso in 2024.

item.title: Federal Agent Shoots Man in Minneapolis, Prompting Tense Protests
item.description: The agent shot a Venezuelan man who was resisting arrest, an official said. Protesters and law enforcement officers clashed for hours, as city officials urged people to go home.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Mitch Smith and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 15, 2026
item.description: Wendy L. Brandes and Barbara Lin make their collaboration debut in the New York Times Crossword.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: BTS está de vuelta con una gira mundial. ¿En qué ciudades darán conciertos?
item.description: Las superestrellas del k-pop harán una gira colosal de regreso: 79 conciertos en cinco continentes en 11 meses. Pero ¿por qué han estado ausentes tanto tiempo?
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:description: BTS actuando en París en 2018 durante un evento que formaba parte de la visita oficial del presidente surcoreano a Francia.

item.title: British Columbia Ends Program That Aimed to Curb Arrests of Drug Users
item.description: The three-year pilot program did not deliver the results hoped for, the health minister said. It had allowed drug users to avoid criminal charges for possessing small amounts of illegal substances.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Chad Hipolito/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Josie Osborne, the minister of health in British Columbia, announced on Wednesday that a drug decriminalization program would end on Jan. 31.

item.title: 3 More Lawmakers in Video Say Federal Prosecutors Are Investigating Them
item.description: The lawmakers, all Democrats who urged military service members not to follow illegal orders, said prosecutors had contacted them. But it is unclear what crime they might have committed.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Representative Jason Crow of Colorado, one of the lawmakers being investigated, said President Trump was “using his political cronies in the Department of Justice to continue to threaten and intimidate us.”

item.title: Boeing Knew About Flaws in UPS Plane That Crashed in Louisville, N.T.S.B. Says
item.description: In a report Wednesday, the National Transportation Safety Board said fractures that appeared to have led the left engine to separate from the plane’s wing had occurred at least four other times.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:description: A drone view of the crash site next to a runway at the Muhammad Ali International Airport, after the crash of a UPS cargo plane in Louisville, Ky., last year.

item.title: Woman Killed by ICE Agent Seemed at Fault, N.Y. Republican Says
item.description: Bruce Blakeman, the likely Republican candidate for governor, said the killing of Renee Good was just one point of disagreement between him and Gov. Kathy Hochul, a Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford and Kristi Berner

media:content.media:description: Bruce Blakeman, the Nassau County executive running for governor, appeared in Albany, N.Y., on Wednesday to criticize Gov. Kathy Hochul’s State of the State speech delivered a day earlier.

item.title: This Might Be the Best Sport for a Longer Life
item.description: Research consistently shows that physical activity is linked to healthy aging. But do some sports confer more longevity benefits than others? Simar Bajaj, a reporting fellow for Well, explains.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj and Theodore Tae

item.title: EE. UU. busca vender el petróleo de Venezuela, su antiguo adversario
item.description: Los funcionarios estadounidenses mediaron en la venta de petróleo venezolano por valor de cientos de millones de dólares para estabilizar la economía del país tras capturar a su presidente.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

media:content.media:description: Una bomba de petróleo en la Faja del Orinoco de Venezuela, la principal zona productora de crudo del país.

item.title: After Danish and U.S. Officials Meet on Greenland, Trump Remains Unmoved
item.description: Denmark’s foreign minister left the White House complex saying that his country had a “fundamental disagreement” with President Trump, as several NATO countries sent troops to Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen of Denmark, center, and Vivian Motzfeldt, Greenland’s minister of foreign affairs, met with U.S. senators on Wednesday.

item.title: Dinamarca, Groenlandia y EE. UU. conversan en medio de las amenazas de Trump
item.description: El objetivo de la discusión era enfocarse en el deseo del presidente Trump de adquirir la isla. Fue la primera reunión entre los tres gobiernos para discutir el tema.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

media:content.media:description: El vicepresidente JD Vance y el secretario de Estado Marco Rubio ante la Casa Blanca el miércoles.

item.title: A Look At Antarctica From Above
item.description: After nearly two weeks at sea without being able to launch his drone, New York Times photographer Chang W. Lee finally captures Antarctica from the air.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Raymond Zhong, Jon Miller, Christina Thornell and Leila Medina

item.title: Prosecutors Say Officer Who Hurled Cooler Was Not Trying to Save Lives
item.description: Lawyers for Sgt. Erik Duran said he had to make a “life-or-death” decision when he struck Eric Duprey as he rode a motorbike recklessly down a sidewalk. Mr. Duprey died almost immediately.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.category: Duran, Erik R (New York, NY, Police Officer)

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sgt. Erik Duran, center, is facing charges of manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and assault in connection to the death of Eric Duprey.

item.title: What Voters Told Democrats About ICE, Rising Costs and Party Perceptions
item.description: In focus groups, swing voters gave Democratic politicians some tough feedback on the party.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Trump Imposes Limited Tariffs on Foreign Semiconductors
item.description: The tariffs will allow President Trump to take a cut of Nvidia’s chip sales to China while putting off a decision about imposing higher taxes on the chip industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:description: Much of the chip industry relies on materials from overseas.

item.title: Ukraine Heat
item.description: Ukraine Heat

media:content.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Denmark Has ‘Fundamental Disagreement’ With U.S. Over Greenland
item.description: On Wednesday, Denmark and Greenland’s foreign ministers met with the Trump administration. President Trump urged the United States needs Greenland for national security purposes but both foreign officials argued Greenland is not up for sale.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:description: Nuuk’s old harbor, Greenland, on Tuesday. People on the island have reacted with shock, anger, confusion and fear to President Trump’s interest in buying or taking over the territory.

item.title: The U.S. Moves Personnel Out of Qatar as Tensions Rise With Iran
item.description: Also, the U.S. and Denmark clash over Greenland. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:description: Members of the military at Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar in May.

item.title: Renaming Defense Department Could Cost Taxpayers $125 Million
item.description: A report released by the Congressional Budget Office estimated the amount of money that would be spent on new signs and letterhead, should Congress approve a change.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: A Department of War placard was displayed on a lectern during a Sept. 11, 2001, commemoration ceremony at the Pentagon in September.

item.title: Iran Postpones Execution of Protester
item.description: Iran postponed the execution of Erfan Soltani, 26, on Wednesday. Soltani would have been the first protester to be executed in the latest wave of antigovernment unrest.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:description: A still from a video posted on social media of cars set on fire during a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: Congress Is Spurning Many of Trump’s Proposed Spending Cuts
item.description: Months after the partisan clash that led to the longest shutdown in history, lawmakers have agreed on spending bills that look far different from what the president wanted.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Capitol last week. The House voted to pass bills to fund the State and Treasury Departments, as well as other foreign aid programs, providing money for agencies the president had proposed eliminating entirely.

item.title: Kaiser Permanente Agrees to Pay $556 Million to Settle Medicare Overbilling Claims
item.description: The Justice Department and whistle-blowers accused the major health insurer of overbilling the government for about $1 billion under the private plans.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dr. James Taylor, a physician and coding expert who worked for Kaiser Permanente, was one of the whistle-blowers who flagged the overbilling. “The cash monster was insatiable,” he said.

item.title: Trump’s Gulf Allies Do Not Want Him to Bomb Iran
item.description: While several of the Gulf Arab countries harbor little love for Iran, they worry that the consequences of rising tensions could blow back on them.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim

media:content.media:description: A patriotic banner in Tehran on Wednesday.

item.title: OpenAI Teams Up With Cerebras in Chip Maker Deal
item.description: The agreement with the start-up Cerebras is the latest in a series intended to expand the A.I. company’s computing power.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz

media:content.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A computer chip made by Cerebras can barely fit in a lap.

item.title: Is Whole Milk Healthier for Kids?
item.description: A new law will allow full-fat and 2 percent milk to be served in schools. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan

media:content.media:credit: Claire Merchlinsky/The New York Times; Photographs by Getty

item.title: Italian Broccoli Salad
item.description: This adaptable make-ahead salad is a great instant lunch or side dish. It starts with raw broccoli florets and stems, thinly sliced into irregular shapes to create many textures.

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.

item.title: Así se gestaron las entrevistas de The New York Times con Petro
item.description: Los reporteros de The New York Times esperaron más de ocho horas para hablar con el presidente Gustavo Petro, quien, como se vio después, tenía otra conversación importante entre manos.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente de Colombia, Gustavo Petro, durante la entrevista que concedió a The New York Times el 7 de enero.

item.title: Newsom Says California Will Not Extradite Abortion Provider to Louisiana
item.description: The case, escalating the interstate battle over abortion, is the second time Louisiana has criminally charged out-of-state doctors with sending abortion pills to Louisiana residents.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck

media:content.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: After the Supreme Court eliminated the national right to abortion in 2022, Gov. Gavin Newsom signed an executive order saying that the state would not extradite health providers accused of providing reproductive health services in other states.

item.title: Fine Arts Panel Postpones Review of Trump’s Ballroom
item.description: The Trump administration has been under pressure from preservationists to submit the ballroom project for a formal review.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A mirror outside the Oval Office on Tuesday reflects the image of a crane working on the site of the demolished East Wing.

item.title: Renee Good’s Family Should Be Able to Sue the Officer Who Killed Her
item.description: An ICE killing in Minneapolis can be the impetus for finally closing a gaping hole in our constitutional protections.
item.dc:creator: Erwin Chemerinsky and Burt Neuborne

item.title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Unhappiness
item.description: One reason for the toxicity of American politics may be that our quality of life is slipping behind our peers’.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof

item.title: H.H.S. Reverses Decision to Cut $2 Billion for Mental Health and Addiction Services
item.description: A day after funding termination notices went out to more than 2,000 programs nationwide, the administration reversed itself and reinstated the money.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.category: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

media:content.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Narcan kit at the Raytown Fire Protection District in Raytown, Mo., in April 2025.

item.title: Frank Dunlop, 98, Dies; Director Who Gave Theater a Free-Spirited Spin
item.description: In 1970, he founded London’s Young Vic, an adventurous “people’s theater” (the Who took the stage at one point) before shaking up the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:description: The theater director and company leader Frank Dunlop in 1977. “Ideas, plans, suggestions issue from him like lava,” one critic said.

item.title: Día 4: prueba una actividad para agudizar tu mente
item.description: Probar cosas nuevas puede ayudar a aumentar tu reserva cognitiva. Hoy te proponemos salir a un museo o entrar a un círculo de lectura.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: Minneapolis ‘Feels Like a Military Occupation’
item.description: President Trump has sent ICE agents into cities across America. We take a look at the fallout and what may come next.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:description: Minneapolis on Tuesday.

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I’m 23. He’s 40.’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Trump no necesitaba autorización para enviar tropas a Venezuela, según un memorando del Departamento de Justicia
item.description: El documento ofrece un panorama detallado de la justificación legal del gobierno de Estados Unidos para la incursión militar en territorio venezolano a principios de enero.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El gobierno de Trump ha empezado a mostrar a los miembros del Congreso un memorando del Departamento de Justicia que aborda de manera general la cuestión de si el presidente Trump necesitaba autorización del Congreso para ordenar la reciente operación militar en Venezuela.

item.title: Trump Administration to Halt Immigrant Visa Processing for 75 Countries
item.description: Federal officials said the move was meant to discourage immigration by people whom they deemed likely to rely on public benefits.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo

media:content.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The pause will affect foreign nationals from countries that include Somalia, Haiti, Iran and Eritrea.
